text: How can we use random sampling to estimate populations?

Random sampling is giving every member of a population an equally likely chance of being selected. Many, if not most, random samples do ‘mirror’ the distribution of population data; however, there are samples that appear not to be from the population even though they are. This is what ‘random sampling’ means. It is important for students to realize that not all samples are ‘good’ samples BUT this does not mean they should then decide that sampling is not worthwhile!

When you use samples to estimate the properties of populations, you never obtain the correct values exactly. Random error is present in all samples. Sample data are not 100% representative of the population because they are not the entire population! Samples can never provide a perfect depiction of the population from which they are drawn.
